title: Verified Purchase
content: In one way or another, my life's work always involved words and how they could be best used.  Not once do I recall ever thinking about how the dictionaries I used came into existence.  That process is the heart of The Dictionary of Lost Worlds, by Pip Williams. This book starts slowly, back to a world without technology, spreadsheets, and even readily available telephones.  It is beautifully written with characters, some fictional and some historically documented.  She tells the story of Esme, who grew up in the creative center of the first Oxford Dictionary of the English Language.  Esme's life reflects the turbulent times in which she lived. She collected words from those around her, some which made it into the dictionary and many which did not. The New York Times review accurately characterized the view as "slyly subversive."  Read this book and you will forever question why some words are acceptable and proper and others are not.  The reasons may surprise you.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: The Dictionary of Lost Words is an engrossing and poignant novel that  touches the heart of the reader. Each character is drawn in such a way as to feel fully real.  The reader is immersed in the details of what it took to complete the Oxford Dictionary while at the same time completely enveloped in the parallel enterprise of creating A Dictionary of Lost Words.  Esme is the character that we take into our hearts as she grows to become a self made scholar as well as all the interesting and endearing people who love and admire her.  There is the theme of the importance and power of words when they are defined and recorded for all time, and the equally important theme to illuminate the struggle for women to be seen and treated with respect.  A beautiful novel, all the more amazing in that it‚Äôs the author‚Äôs first.  I look forward to the next one.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2023

title: Beautiful Novel
content: Unparalleled: having no parallel or equal; exceptional.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: This book covers a gap in history that is truly astounding. The concept (which is based on very real events and mostly real people) is so intriguing, and Pip has fastened it all together with such literary grace. I WILL SAY, that for the first half of the book I was considering giving it a 3 star rating. I liked the storyline but it was a bit slow paced for me. KEEP READING. It really picks up and by time you get to the end you will ‚Äúget the morbs‚Äù (a definitions stolen from the book, which means you will be struck with melancholy) due to the beauty and truth of Esme‚Äôs story. So many times the endings of stories disappoint, but not this time. If you love a healthy dose of feminism, are intrigued by words, or just want a good story that will suck you in, then you should most certainly order this book.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2023

title: Exceptional
content: There are so many good things that can be said about this book, but the best might just be that, if you‚Äôre looking to fall into another world for awhile, and enjoy doing such a thing more when you know you have a trusted guide, trust Ms. Williams, and trust this book. The storyline is wonderful and creative, while staying true to its course. The characters, both real and imagined, are indistinguishable and fit as if they all actually lived in this time. The consciousness of the themes in the book is great, so much so that you as reader are given the chance to absorb those themes as if you newly discovered them, rather than being force fed the themes, all because the author curated them so well for you/us. And the writing is as thoughtful as the work that those who compiled the OED gave, but far more enjoyable to read:) Kudos.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2023

title: Verified Purchase
content: I enjoyed the book. I had read the summary  enough times that I thought I had already read it when my book club this was our book. Glad I went back & actually read it. I knew putting together a dictionary would be no easy task but never really thought about how it was actually done. Also I knew the process was not short but never imagined it took that long. Of course the war didn't help. The gathering of words and printing them into the first dictionary is told from a woman's point of view in a man's world. Not only do you understand the way the dictionary came about but the surrounding events that had  an effect on it's coming to publication. I thought it an interesting read and would recommend it to friends.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: All of the words listed above describe this book which is primarily a story about the composition of the Oxford English Dictionary as experienced by the fictional protagonist. Words matter to each of us in different ways, our meanings slightly shaded by our experiences. Loss is such a word and rendered in the book through the experience of losing a parent, losing a slip of paper, losing one's virginity, losing perspective. The loss of a life, the loss of language, the loss of purpose.

title: Verified Purchase
content: "Dictionary of Lost Words" delicately navigates through sensitive topics like women's rights, traditional gender roles, abortion, and adoption. Through its nuanced exploration, it amplifies voices often silenced. This meticulously crafted book is a poignant reminder of the power of language in shaping narratives and reclaiming lost stories. A compelling read that resonates long after the final page is turned.

title: Verified Purchase
content: This book was recommended by a friend and was a delight to read. The main character is a woman lexicographer in England. The reader is drawn into her life when she is a child working alongside her father, one of the lexiographers responsible for creating the dictionary that determined which words would describe the English world. As a historical novel the work is laudable. The narrative is engaging with a sub-text that philosophical calls into question the early practice of letting only formally educated white men catalog which words were historically worth preserving and passing on into common usage. A sheer delight for the manner in which it uncovers and sheds light on how the words, and therefore the worlds, of women, the poor and the pedestrian among us, became distorted or lost (hence the dictionary of lost words). Oe of the best books of the decade, IMHO.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2022

title: Wonderful!
content: I loved this book. As a retired publisher, the focus on word choice, editing, typesetting, printing, & binding alone would have been enough. But this story about the painstaking efforts of both real & fictional editors and compilers was engrossing. The story encompassed a range of social and historic issues, from class and gender roles to the women's suffrage movement and WWI.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2021

title: Verified Purchase
content: Raised by her widowed father, Esme lives a sheltered childhood in Oxford, England, accompanying him to his work as a senior editor for the new Oxford English Dictionary. Words chosen for inclusion must be vetted, researched, and finally approved. The process is slow, and the story unfolds by years and sections of the alphabetical dictionary entries. As a child and later an assistant to the editorial team, Esme comes to realize that discarded words without literary attributions (or those deemed inappropriate by the men who make the final decisions) deserve recognition, and that most of them are commonly used by women.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2023

title: What a beautiful story
content: There are several love stories -- among dear friends, colleagues, family, and true love -- and heartaches, deftly written as Esme matures. Highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys a rich historical novel based on the esteemed reference dictionary. Who knew there might be such an interesting backstory?!

title: different Kind of Story
content: I enjoyed this novel about the creation of the Oxford Dictionary of the English Language. It was a time consuming project, and the author places young women in the midst of the older gentlemen editors. They editors decided which words were worthy of inclusion and which were not. Esme, one of the young women, felt all words should be included so she compiled her own Dictionary of Lost Words. The book passes through times of women trying to get the vote and the 1st World War.  The best parts were about Esme‚Äôs quest to finds women‚Äùs words.  It was an enjoyable as well as thought-provoking read.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: The title immediately drew me in, and from the first word I was hooked. The bond of a father and daughter over words spoke to me. As a journalist, words are beautiful things and this book makes you appreciate that.

title: Moving and illuminating
content: I just finished reading the book and I'm ready to start reading it again. That rarely happens for me. Of late I've read a number of period and historic novels with female protagonists.  They were well written, but none of them reached in and grabbed my heart as this one did.  It is a book about words, and those who love words, and the writing style is both poetic and succinct. Visual. Visceral.  Glorious use of words to tell both the history of the Oxford Dictionary and the complex life story of Esme.  What a wonderful film or limited series this would make, and I can imagine a sequel. Looking forward to more novels by Pip Williams,
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: As with any major undertaking, intended to be thorough, there is success. And wanting. In this, the earlier edition of the OED failed to embrace a significant group of words, excluded because the defining terms were not sufficiently elastic to accommodate them. Ms Williams has given us splendid story of how many of those sidelined words were collected, using the same meticulous scrutiny and standard of the 'official' group.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2021

title: This is an extraordinary book!
content: I have, in my recent reading, settled upon a fascination with books, libraries...and now, the words...that are woven & crafted into books, populating libraries. This book is highly recommended: it is well-written, better: well-crafted. The characters are animated, dimensional. It provides a history of the words that far-too-often have been dismissed, for (in hindsight) spurious and negligent reasons. The book doesn't make any sort of reparation; it does, however, add texture, substance, to a hitherto unrecorded history. Well done, ma'am, well done!
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2021
